JUnit is not "installed" with Maven in the traditional sense. Instead,
Mave=
n automatically downloads the JUnit jars (and other jars that your
applicat=
ion requires, as declared via <dependencies> in the pom.xml
file) when you =
run Maven.

You might want to check out the free pdf "Better Builds with Ma=
ven" to
get a better sense for what Maven is and how it works etc. A lot of=
 us
are big fans of the tool, but there are also many people who dislike
it=
 for various reasons.

Wayne
